issues.title: daytona env set does not register delete of env vars

labels.name: never stale
labels.description: An issue that never goes stale

issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
When executing `daytona env set` with aim to delete certain environment variables set before, those deleted are not registered as deleted.
Instead, they are still shown on executing `daytona env list`.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Execute `daytona env set`
2. Add some environment variables
3. Execute `daytona env list`
4. Execute `daytona env set`
5. Delete a subset of previously added environment variables
6. Execute `daytona env list` again

**Expected behavior**
It is expected that once deleted environment variables are really deleted.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: [e.g. Ubuntu 22.04]
 - Daytona Version: [e.g. v0.24.0]

issues.title: SHA is not set when parsing static git context for GitLab repositories in "commits/" scenario

labels.name: never stale
labels.description: An issue that never goes stale

issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
When parsing static git context for GitLab repositories in `commits/` scenario, only the branch property is set to the parsed value. The URL structure in GitLab repositories accepts both a branch name or SHA as a "Git revision" to follow after `commits/`.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Parse static git context for https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/commits/c87cfbb77c2cf36356d010d1c0b21817c42f70ef
2. Confirm that SHA property is not set, only the branch property

**Expected behavior**
SHA property in the static git context should be set

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - Daytona Version: [v0.24.0]

issues.title: Daytona in Daytona profile conflict

labels.name: never stale
labels.description: An issue that never goes stale

issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
When running Daytona in Daytona, the profile inside the project points to the server that created the project.
Because of this, `dtn serve` will not create a new default profile that points to it and the user will be unable to connect to the local server.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Run `daytona create https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona --code`
2. Observe that `daytona ls` inside the project lists workspaces from the "host server"
3. Run `dtn serve` to start the local server
4. Observer that `daytona ls` again points to the "host server" and you are unable to connect to the local server without wiping the config first

**Expected behavior**
`dtn serve` inside the project should create a config that is separate from the config created by `daytona agent` so that the user can use both CLIs freely.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Mac
 - Daytona Version: v0.23.1

issues.title: Daytona installation fails on macOS with 'launchctl: failed with stderr: Unload failed: 5: Input/output error'

labels.name: never stale
labels.description: An issue that never goes stale

issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
The Daytona server installation process on macOS is failing when attempting to stop the existing Daytona server daemon. The error suggests an issue with the launchctl command used to manage system services on macOS.

**To Reproduce**
1. On a macOS system, run the Daytona installation script over the existing Daytona installation 0.23.0
2. When the script attempts to stop the existing Daytona server, observe the error

**Expected behavior**
The installation script should successfully stop the existing Daytona server and proceed with the installation of the new version without errors.

**Screenshots**
![Screenshot showing the terminal output with the launchctl error during Daytona installation on macOS](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/06752e48-c4a5-4ea4-bb2f-d1e90842b273)

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: macOS Sonoma
 - Daytona Version: 0.23.1

**Additional context**
The error message suggests running "launchctl bootout" as root for more detailed error information. This might be a necessary troubleshooting step for the development team. The issue appears to be specific to the macOS service management system and may require adjustments to how Daytona interacts with launchd on macOS.

issues.title: daytona code non valid WS name

labels.name: never stale
labels.description: An issue that never goes stale

issues.body:
**Describe the bug**  
When attempting to run the `daytona code` command with a GitHub URL or anything that is not a valid WS name, an error occurs indicating that the page was not found. The product expects a workspace name, so the error message should indicate this requirement and suggest a human-readable error message.

**To Reproduce**  
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Open the terminal.
2. Enter the command: `daytona code https://github.com/xxx/yyy`
3. Press Enter.
4. See error message: `FATA[0000] 404 page not found`

**Expected behavior**  
The command should return a human-readable error message indicating that a workspace name is required, such as: `Error: Workspace name required. Please provide a valid workspace name with the command. You can see all workspace names by running the command _daytona list_.`

issues.title: Start Docker if not running
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
When i start Daytona and docker is not running I the get error:
`FATA[0000] Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running? 
`

**Describe the solution you'd like**
1. A more user-friendly error message instead of `FATA[0000]`. Preferably, the message should be: C`annot connect to the Docker daemon. Is the Docker daemon running?`
2. Following the error message, a prompt should ask:` Would you like to start the Docker daemon? (Y/N)`
3. If the user selects 'Y', the system should attempt to start the Docker daemon from the terminal and then restart Daytona if successful.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Consider the possibility that Docker may not be installed. In such a case, provide a secondary error message: `Cannot start Docker. It may not be installed. Please refer to the documentation here: [XYZ Documentation Link].`

This was branched from/suggested in #765

issues.title: using Podman causes failure to pull the registry image

labels.name: never stale
labels.description: An issue that never goes stale

issues.body:
**Describe the bug**

```
[sven@p1gen4:~/src/daytona]$ DOCKER_HOST=unix:///run/user/1000/podman/podman.sock ./daytona serve
INFO[0000] Starting Daytona server                      
INFO[0000] Starting local container registry            
Pulling image...
FATA[0000] Error response from daemon: failed to parse "X-Registry-Auth" header for /v1.41/images/create?fromImage=registry&tag=2.8.3: invalid character 'z' looking for beginning of value 
```

The cause appears to be a workaround for non-authenticated registry use - see https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona/blob/main/pkg/docker/pull_image.go#L77

```
func getRegistryAuth(cr *containerregistry.ContainerRegistry) string {
	if cr == nil {
		// Sometimes registry auth fails if "" is sent, so sending "empty" instead
		return "empty"
	}
..
```

When I replace the `"empty"` with `""`, podman happily pulls the `registry:2.8.3` image, and then falls over using the docker-provider to pull the image when creating a new workspace.

I'm unsure when the "Sometimes" is - hopefully, it's for a specific registry that we can identify and test for?

issues.title: A Git Provider should support multiple identities for the same user
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
With reference to discussions in the [issue](https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona/issues/761), Users having multiple accounts or multiple access tokens for a git provider (each with their own permissions, access to different organizations and repos) might need the requirement to have the ability to use repos and organizations limited for a specific token.
(Can have multiple access tokens within the same account also, ex - separate tokens for public and private repos)

Currently, the command for adding a new git provider just asks for a access token and overrides any existing token (if exists). To move back to previous identity, he/she will need to add back the corresponding token for a git provider. This requires the user to remember the access tokens (last used) for their specific needs. Overall, only a single identity is supported at a time.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
`daytona gp add` command must ask user to provide unique identity names for each token.
And subsequently `daytona create` command will need the user to input the identity name first. 

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
None or N/A

**Additional context**
The implementation plan is open to suggestions, nothing is finalized yet.

Edit: Also includes https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona/issues/777#issuecomment-2230286955

issues.title: Workspace creation times out on stable slow connections
issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
When creating a workspace, we have a 3-minute timeout after a project starts to establish a connection.
The issue is that for slow connections, downloading the binary might take longer than 3 minutes which will cause the process to fail.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Throttle internet connection to ~10mbps
2. Daytona create

issues.title: Persistent logging
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
The Daytona server occasionally crashes due to various reasons, and without persistent logging, diagnosing these issues is challenging.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Implement a persistent logging mechanism:
- Logs should be written to a file or centralized logging service (potentially related to centralised profiles).
- Use different log levels (INFO, DEBUG, WARN, ERROR).
- Implement log rotation to manage disk usage.

issues.title: Improve command aliases consistency and representation in "help"
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Daytona's commands use many different aliases for some command verbs - for example `daytona target set` has aliases `"s", "add", "update", "register", "edit"` while . We should revisit some of these commands and figure out a standardized way of choosing the main command and the aliases it comes with.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The main verbs and their respective aliases used in the commands should be consistent even if it means removing some aliases that make sense at first. These changes should also be clearly reflected in the content of the "help" manual for each command and have the relevant aliases listed.

**Additional context**
#748 mentions the `daytona api-key generate` aka `daytona api-key new` being confusing and the aliases not being listed as part of the integrated Cobra "help" command

issues.title: Align component naming
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Component naming is not aligned with other products in the same dev tools space. It can confuse the new users and complicate the naming of new components and features.

Daytona uses the following components to define the relationship between applications (e.g., repositories) that are being developed. These components are:

**Project** - a container instance of a development environment consisting of OS, runtime, source code, packages and libraries, and development tools needed to develop an application. Each Project is related to a single application repository.
**Project configuration** - a configuration schema for the Project instance (e.g., custom base image, builder configuration, environment variables, etc.) (WIP)
**Workspace** - a set of related Projects (one or more) that can interact with one another over the Workspace network. The Workspace provides the interface that the user interacts with (to create, start, stop, or destroy a workspace).
**Workspace Template** - a configuration schema that allows instant creation of predefined Workspaces (WIP).

Compared with other products in the same dev tools space, it indicates that Daytona's naming is not aligned with other products in the space.

| Daytona               | AWS CodeCatalyst | Azure DevBox      | Cloud Workspaces          | OpenShift DevSpaces | GitHub Codespaces | Gitpod            | Codesandbox |
|-----------------------|------------------|-------------------|---------------------------|---------------------|-------------------|-------------------|-------------|
| Workspace Template    | Blueprint (?)    | ?                 | N/A                       | N/A                 | N/A               | N/A               | N/A         |
| Workspace             | Project          | Project           | Workstation Cluster (*)   | N/A                 | N/A               | N/A               | N/A         |
| Project Configuration | N/A (**)         | DevBox Definition | Workstation Configuration | N/A (Devfile)       | Prebuild          | N/A (gitpod.yaml) | N/A         |
| Project               | Dev Env          | DevBox            | Workstation               | Workspace           | Codespace         | Workspace         | DevBox      |

* Workstation Cluster defines the cluster location for related Workstation instances.  It is not strictly comparable to the CodeCatalyst or DevBox Project component, but in that same way, it serves the purpose of grouping the instance.
** CodeCatalyst does not provide the interface to customize the DevBox instance, but the instance itself includes (and is probably built from) the devfile. I assume that customizing the instance will be possible in the future.

The Workspace and Project components in Daytona are used in very different contexts in other products.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
We need to align the naming of Daytona's components so that they don't confuse the new users.

issues.title: Devcontainer non-blocking commands executed in the foreground
issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
With repos such as https://github.com/metcalfc/simple-astro/tree/main, where the `postAttachCommand` is a long-running process, the workspace creation process gets stuck forever. Additionally, the creation process always executes all user commands in the foreground when, in reality, they can be executed in the background while allowing the user to connect to the project.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. `daytona create https://github.com/metcalfc/simple-astro/tree/main`
2. Observe that the workspace creation process is stuck on running the `postAttachCommand`

**Expected behavior**
Non-blocking commands are executed in the background and, in the meantime, the user is allowed to connect to the project.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: any
 - Daytona Version: v0.21.1
 - Docker Provider Version: v0.7.1

**Additional context**
This should be solved by using `--skip-non-blocking-commands` in `devcontainer up` and then running `devcontainer run-user-commands` in the background.

issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
The current create flow depends on the server image builder step that introduces unnecessary container registry action slowing down the creation time and filling up the local cr.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The creation flow should process the dev env configuration on the target instance, leaving the server image builder for the prebuilds feature to use only.

issues.title: Appropriately handle missing logs error
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
When the workspace creation request is submitted to the server, the server logs a few errors regarding to missing workspace/project logs. The CLI retries the endpoint until the logs become available so this does not present a usage issue but a UX one.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
We should find a solution that suppresses these logs so the user is not concerned with them.

issues.title: Missing terminal cursor after cancelling workspace creation

labels.name: never stale
labels.description: An issue that never goes stale

issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
Sometimes, when the user cancels the workspace creation process, the terminal cursor goes missing and can't be recovered. See the attached screen recording for a demonstration.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Run `daytona create https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona`
2. Wait for the logs to reach the devcontainer build process
3. Abort the process with `Ctrl+C`
4. Observe that the cursor is missing

**Expected behavior**
The cursor should be visible in the terminal normally.

**Screenshots**

https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona/assets/26512078/f1556c7f-754c-475b-925c-928a7f6dcf8a


**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: any
 - Daytona Version: v0.19.1

**Additional context**
I assume the issue occurs because of logs that are manipulating the cursor. We should ensure that it is reset after the user cancels the process.

issues.title: Validate devcontainer config file name
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
The Devcontainer CLI will fail if the config file is not named `.devcontainer.json` or `devcontainer.json`. Currently, our TUI allows for any path to be entered which will fail during the build process if the condition is not met.

```
Error: Filename must be devcontainer.json or .devcontainer.json
```

**Describe the solution you'd like**
We should implement input validation that would inform the user during the creation process that the filename must be named `.devcontainer.json` or `devcontainer.json`.

issues.title: Notify user if the server ports are taken on startup
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Suppose the user tries to start Daytona while another instance is already started (or another process is taking the server ports). In that case, the startup process will exit without notifying the user about the problem.

![Screenshot from 2024-06-12 13-19-51](https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona/assets/13081153/58e63d79-6e97-4122-8d71-976d7ebd9f3a)

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The user should be notified about the problem before the startup process exits.

issues.title: Docker running out of disk space when creating devcontainers
issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
While creating a workspace from a repo with dev container, an error is raised indicating that there is no space left on the device, despite having sufficient space on the remote target.

The process fails with the error message "ERROR: failed to solve: failed to prepare p1hwxc089qshhn1a2xuddosnu as m5rerz06teexqxpjlvnv60hnq: no space left on device".

The issue seems to be related to the local machine running out of disk space allocated to Docker, even though the remote machine has sufficient storage. The user has allocated 64GB of disk space to Docker on their Mac, but it appears that this is not enough for the devcontainer creation process.

This problem poses a significant challenge from a user experience standpoint, as even with a small number of simple Git repositories, the devcontainer creation process requires more than 64GB of local disk space allocated to docker.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: MacOs Sonoma and Ubuntu 22.04 on remote
 - Daytona Version: v0.18.0

issues.title: Improve Provider requirement handling
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Providers can have certain OS requirements that should be met by the host machine. For example, the Docker provider requires docker to be installed and running. Currently, the Docker provider will throw a fatal error if docker is not running preventing the user from starting the server even though the user might not even use the local target.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
We should implement a solution that will inform the user about the requirements of the provider and what might not work correctly if they are not met. I propose that we implement a method in the provider that can return the description of the requirements that will be logged on server startup. Additionally, the method response should include requirements that are met (which can be logged with INFO) and those that are not (which can be logged as a warning for the user)

**Additional context**
Related to #671

issues.title: Improve daemon startup logging
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently, we only inform the user that we are starting the Daytona server in daemon mode. The biggest issue with this occurs if the startup process fails. In this case, the user can only see the fatal error with no info as to what happened.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
We should add server logs while its starting in daemon mode to improve UX

**Additional context**
Related to #671

issues.title: Expose server CLI version
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Since Daytona can be used with a remote profile to a server not running on the users machine, they can run different versions of Daytona which could lead to incompatibilities between them.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I suggest we attach `X-Server-Version` to all API responses and `X-Client-Version` to all client requests. This would allow the server and CLI to know which respective version of Daytona is used.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I considered exposing the Server version as a separate endpoint but using headers seems much more streamlined.

**Additional context**
If a version mismatch is detected, we can display a warning message to the CLI user and suggest they upgrade either their local or remote Daytona binary.

issues.title: Too many FATAL errors on daytona exit
issues.body: **Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.** If you quit from a daytona TUI like the profile, you'll get a FATAL error. That isn't an error, that was intended. If you ctrl-c out of the main TUI, you get a FATAL error. It looks unpolished. If there was an error and we want the user to do something we should prompt for it. If there is some useful info, we should present it. But the way its presented: Looks like these are all unhandled errors. **Describe the solution you'd like** Only present FATAL errors when there actually are errors. Otherwise, there should be either no output (in the case of user quitting), or human formatted input in the case there is an error or something we want the user to understand. Tracking some related issues: https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona/issues/615 https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona/issues/643 https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona/issues/646

labels.name: never stale

issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
I upgraded and daytona wasn't running. So I ran `daytona server start` and got this error:

```
❯ daytona server start

 Starting the Daytona Server daemon...

FATA[0001] Init already exists: /home/metcalfc/.config/systemd/user/DaytonaServerDaemon.service
```


**Expected behavior**
I'd expect that `daytona server start` could handle the file existing and instead of throwing an error, tell the user that the service is running.  For example, you can "start" a service in systemd as often as you want. If its running, it doesn't even say anything because the desired outcome, the service running is true.

```
metcalfc in 🌐 boxloader in ~

issues.title: Script to uninstall Daytona
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
As a Daytona user, I want to entirely remove Daytona and any directories/files it may have created during installation or runtime.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A one-line script I can run to uninstall Daytona entirely from the system. It should remove the binary, config, any images, etc. returning the system to the state it was in before Daytona was installed.

**Additional context**
In reference to documentation issue daytonaio/docs#54

I've considered documenting it manually for users in the docs, but this doesn't provide a great user experience. It also requires maintenance of instructions in the docs that could easily be scripted as the installation procedure is.

When using a package manager, there's a one-line method of uninstalling a package and cleaning up any leftover files/directories. e.g. `brew uninstall git`, `dnf uninstall podman`, etc. With the recommended installation of Daytona, this doesn't exist.

Since we have an installation script, we should make uninstalling Daytona just as straightforward for the user.

issues.title: GitHub workflow to build Daytona binaries within PRs
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
As a docs writer, I need to efficiently test new features and breaking changes in advance of a new Daytona release. The earlier I can get a build including a specific feature, the better.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I'm proposing adding a GitHub workflow to the repository that runs in the context of a PR. When a new commit is pushed in a PR, it builds the binaries and uploads them as artifacts. I can pull the binary from the PR and install it in a fresh local environment for testing.

Aside from this being a solution to the above, this change would also be a build verification steps for Daytona's development process.

**Additional context**
Relevant docs: https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/storing-workflow-data-as-artifacts#uploading-build-and-test-artifacts

issues.title: Allow external build registry configuration
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently, the Daytona Server spins up a build registry locally that the builders then push to and providers pull from. This is not ideal since it always bloats the users machine and prevents users from using preconfigured registries.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
As part of `daytona server configure` users should be able to configure an external registry that Daytona Builders can then push to. The configuration must include the URL and authentication (user, token). 

**Additional context**
In the configuration screen, the user could always switch back to using the local registry.

issues.title: Allow builder images to be configurable
issues.body:

Currently, we hardcode the builder image to `daytonaio/workspace-project`.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
This should be configurable as part of `daytona server configure`.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
As part of this issue, we should discuss if the user should be able to configure a custom image for each builder (DevContainer, Docker, etc.) or one image that is used by all builders.

issues.title: Docker Image Caching / Updating Strategy
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

There are several issues combined here. The first is that it would be helpful if the images that are pulled are cached locally (for example in the Docker engine image store). Caching means subsequent workspaces will load faster, Docker Hub rate limits can be avoided, home bandwidth limits too. 

The challenge is that many images especially in dev container use semver tags. For example the same image will be tagged `1`, `1.1`, and `1.2.3` if want to be explicit about deps you pin to `1.2.3`, if you're willing to take security fixes you pin `1.1`, and if you'll take anything so long as the interface is the same you can pin `1`. 

So the virtual tags `1` and `1.2` will be pushed over. So you'll always be up-to-date if you pull every time. 

This requires that you pull the metadata and compare against the cache everytime. This isn't the typical Docker behavior but when you want to stay current on dev env this is the better approach to balance caching and up-to-dateness.


**Describe the solution you'd like**

Cache the images locally on pull, on ever pull compare the metadata for the tag against what is in the cache and pull again or not.

Docker Compose for example does both: In the screenshot above. The TUI dotted squares show total image progress. And each row shows layer progress. **Describe alternatives you've considered** Its helpful to understand that its the pull that is taking time. Because this is an area that you can decide to spend more or less time to try to make the images smaller if it always takes a long time. Or move to a different host. Understanding that also makes it clear that its not an issue with Daytona.

issues.title: Rename Workspace to Dev Environment

labels.name: never stale
labels.description: An issue that never goes stale

issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Renaming "workspace" to "dev environment" in DAYTONA can significantly improve clarity. The term "dev environment" is more specific and recognizable to developers, as it directly indicates a space meant for development-related tasks. 

This specificity eliminates the ambiguity associated with the generic term "workspace," which can refer to any work area and not necessarily development.

Additionally, adopting "dev environment" aligns with industry standards and practices. Example; Docker uses "dev environments" to describe its configurable spaces for development. On the other hand, GitHub uses "codespaces" for its cloud-hosted development environments, while reserving "workspaces" for different purposes within their broader ecosystem

On an account where shell configuration is managed by [`home-manager`](https://github.com/nix-community/home-manager), attempting to purge data using the CLI fails due to permissions issues. `home-manager` assumes ownership of some configuration files when managing the user shell, including the main `fish` configuration when `fish` is enabled: https://github.com/nix-community/home-manager/blob/master/modules/programs/fish.nix

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Execute `daytona purge` on an account managed by Nix home-manager, where the shell is managed by home-manager.
2. Confirm that you want to purge all data.

**Expected behavior**
`daytona purge` reports the error to the user but continues with any outstanding steps in purging all configs/data relating to Daytona. The error isn't classed as fatal.

More broadly, the steps of `daytona purge` should be left to the package manager to clean up in instances where Daytona isn't installed using the script.

issues.title: Project and workspace API keys are not stored in the DB
issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
Project and workspace API keys are not stored in the DB which means that any workspace or project request (except for `create`) to the provider does not have an API key of the resource attached. This bug was undetected because the Docker provider attaches the API key as a container variable to the project, so when the project starts, it gets the API key from the env. In the case of VM-based providers, this presents an issue because when starting up a workspace, a missing API key will lead to failure when downloading the Daytona binary again.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. The easiest way to reproduce is to debug the Daytona server and observe that the API key is missing when calling `StartWorkspace` on a provider.

**Expected behavior**
Project and workspace API keys should be attached to every request made to the provider which means they should be stored in the database.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: any
 - Daytona Version: v0.16.0

issues.title: Logging refactor
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Workspace and project logs are written to from multiple sources (Daytona, Providers, etc.). This leads to issues on how to display certain logs because the CLI does not differentiate between, for example, pull progress, push progress, state messages, workspace or project logs, etc.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
We should look to how Docker (and similar tools) handle progress messages. Docker streams "events" to the CLI and the CLI then decides on how to display the message based on the terminal size. Having log entries as JSON object would also make it easier for us to style and manipulate logs in the most appropriate way based on terminal size (or other properties).

**Additional context**
This feature will require providers to update their logging strategy as well. Because of this, it's important that our `logger` library is well structured.

issues.title: Project dial fails for large repos

labels.name: never stale
labels.description: An issue that never goes stale

issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
After a project is created, we wait for it to start the tailscale server and we check that we can dial to it. For large repos, cloning can take a while, more than the 3 min dial timeout we set, so the creation command will report a dial timeout.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Create a workspace from a large repo (e.g. `daytona create https://gitlab.com/idagelic/inkscape`)
2. Observe that the creation process exceeded the 3-min timeout because the repo didn't finish cloning.

**Expected behavior**
The workspace should create successfully. I recommend we only start dialing the project once we are sure that the tailscale server started booting up. We could add a line to the logs from the agent that the creation process can then use as a trigger for the dial.

**Screenshots**

issues.title: Git service doesn't clone branch when it should
issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
An example of a valid git repository passed to a project would be:
```json
"repository": {
        "branch": "branch-test",
        "id": "",
        "name": "",
        "owner": "daytonaio",
        "prNumber": 8,
        "sha": "693eebceea8d7590eb965c08645500e31a477bdb",
        "source": "github.com",
        "url": "https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona.git"
      }
```

But because of the `shouldCloneBranch` method of the git service, the branch is not cloned.
```golang
func (s *Service) shouldCloneBranch(project *workspace.Project) bool {
	if project.Repository.Branch == nil || *project.Repository.Branch == "" {
		return false
	}

	if project.Repository.Sha == "" {
		return true
	}

	return *project.Repository.Branch == project.Repository.Sha
}
```


**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Create a workspace with a project that has a branch attached.
2. Observe that the repo will not be cloned on the appropriate branch

**Expected behavior**
The repo should be cloned on the appropriate branch. The `shouldCloneBranch` method should be changed to:
```golang
func (s *Service) shouldCloneBranch(project *workspace.Project) bool {
	if project.Repository.Branch == nil || *project.Repository.Branch == "" {
		return false
	}

	if project.Repository.Sha == "" {
		return true
	}

	return *project.Repository.Branch != project.Repository.Sha
}
```

We need to check that the branch is different from the SHA because in the case where a user wants to checkout a specific commit, the SHA and branch will be the same and in that case the `shouldCheckoutSha` function should return `true`.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: any
 - Daytona Version: v0.15.0

issues.title: Ensure CLI API calls are heading towards the Daytona Server API
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Because we decided to run the Daytona Server on a very popular port (3000), users often have clashes with the Server API and another http server on the same port. This leads to hard-to-debug issues because it's difficult to tell if the error came from the Daytona API or another server that's holding the port.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
We could implement a route on the Daytona API that the CLI can use before making actual requests to make sure that it's heading towards the Daytona Server API. The API already has a `/health` route and we could make a HEAD request to it or create a new route specifically for this purpose.

A HEAD request to `/health` seems reasonable enough but other suggestions are welcome.

issues.title: Projects that have a broken tailscale connection for more than 5 minutes can not reestablish it
issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
If a project's tailscale connection is broken for more than 5 minutes (e.g. the server is stopped for more than 5 minutes), the connection can not be reestablished. This is due to how the headscale server is configured and due to the fact that projects use ephemeral network keys.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Run the Daytona Server
2. Create a workspace and observe that you can use `daytona ssh/code` to connect to it.
3. Stop the Daytona Server for more than 5 minutes, then start it again
4. Observe that you can not connect to the same workspace you created in step 2.

**Expected behavior**
Projects should be able to reestablish a connection to the server no matter how long the connection was broken for.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: any
 - Daytona Version: v0.14.0

**Additional context**
There are 3 possible solutions to the issue:
1. Increase the [ephemeral inactivity timeout](https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona/blob/main/pkg/server/headscale/config.go#L32) to a bigger duration.
2. Allow projects to create non-ephemeral network keys. This would require the removal of created network keys once the workspace is removed.
3. Introduce a retry policy in the agent that would attempt to regenerate an ephemeral network key if the tailscale connection is broken.

I favor approach 3 over 2, and avoid 1 as that could lead to node pileup on the headscale server.

issues.title: Issues/PRs should not go stale if they are awaiting interaction for Datyona Org

labels.name: never stale
labels.description: An issue that never goes stale

issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
Issues and PRs are incorrectly flagged as "stale" if someone from the Daytona Org does not interact with them in a timely manner. This should not occur, as it implies the issue was not addressed.

**To Reproduce**
Create an issue or PR as a (non-Daytona Org) user. If no one from the Daytona team responds, it will become stale.

**Expected behavior**
Issues should only be marked as stale if the last comment was made by a Daytona Org member. This would indicate that Daytona is awaiting further input from the user. If the user does not respond, then the issue can be considered no longer important or valid.

**Additional context**
Currently, neither the Probot Stale bot nor the standard GitHub Actions for marking issues and PRs as stale directly support the specific functionality of checking the identity of the last commenter before marking items as stale. Both primarily rely on activity (or the lack thereof), regardless of whether the last interaction was from a repository owner, member, or external contributor.
However, you can achieve this behavior by customizing a GitHub Action. By creating a custom action, you can script it to check the identity of the last commenter and then decide whether to mark the issue or PR as stale based on whether the last comment was made by a member of your organization. Here’s a basic outline of how you might set this up using GitHub Actions and the GitHub API:
Create a Custom GitHub Action Workflow:
You’ll create a workflow in your .github/workflows directory. This action will use the GitHub API to fetch the latest comments on each issue and PR, check the author of the last comment, and then apply a stale label only if the last comment was not made by an organization member.
Sample Workflow:
Here’s a simple example to get you started. This script uses the GitHub API to fetch issues and their comments, checks the commenter's association to the repository, and marks the issue as stale if the conditions are met.

```
name: "Mark Stale Issues and PRs"
on:
  schedule:
    - cron: '0 0 * * *'  # Runs every day at midnight
jobs:
  stale:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v2
      - name: Mark stale issues/PRs
        uses: actions/github-script@v5
        with:
          github-token: ${{secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN}}
          script: |
            const org = 'your-org'; // Your GitHub org/user
            const repo = 'your-repo'; // Your repository
            const response = await github.rest.issues.listForRepo({
              owner: org,
              repo: repo,
              state: 'open',
            });
            const issues = response.data;
            for (const issue of issues) {
              const comments = await github.rest.issues.listComments({
                owner: org,
                repo: repo,
                issue_number: issue.number,
              });
              const lastComment = comments.data.pop();
              if (lastComment && lastComment.user.type !== 'OrganizationMember') {
                // Add logic to mark as stale here
                await github.rest.issues.addLabels({
                  owner: org,
                  repo: repo,
                  issue_number: issue.number,
                  labels: ['stale'],
                });
              }
            }
```
Adjust the Script:
Modify the script to fit your specific requirements, such as checking for specific types of comments, or adding additional labels or comments when marking as stale.
Ensure your repository secrets (GITHUB_TOKEN) are set correctly to allow the script to authenticate and perform actions on your repository.
Test and Deploy:
Test the action thoroughly in a test repository to make sure it behaves as expected.
Once confirmed, deploy it in your production repository to start automatically managing stale issues and PRs based on the last commenter's association.

issues.title: daytona create --shell
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Similar to a cloud shell, I'd like to be able to start a Daytona workspace with no repo attached.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Its the same flow as `daytona create` except without a repository specified and the additional `--shell` parameter.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
The cloud shells are similar or docker run image. But eventually I'd like the all the goodness of the future versions of daytona workspaces, ide integration, dotfiles capability, automatic credentials (via plugins), etc.

issues.title: Suggest workspace name that doesn't already exist
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Using `daytona create` can open a workspace name prompt with the suggestion being a name that is already in use. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Adding a number suffix such as workspace -> workspace2 would be useful

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Pressing enter and getting the workspace already exists error then changing manually

issues.title: Replace workspace ID UUID with short UUID
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Workspace IDs are UUIDs currently, which is a bit too verbose.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The ID of the workspace can be a short UUID and that will make it easier to generate project hostnames as well. Project hostname can then just be `Trim(workspaceId+projectName, 60)`.

issues.title: Use random characters in Workspace name
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

I'm always frustrated when doing a demo or lecture as I often use the same repo, and I need to think about the name of the workspace to make sure it's not in use.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

My suggestion is to use random characters in the default name Daytona generates. Here's how it could work:

1. Combine Git username and repository name with a dash in between, for example: `johndoe-repo`
2. Append a dash and 10 random characters to the end, for example: `johndoe-repo-kdxsst47fc`
3. Limit the length to 24 characters

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

I've considered removing the Git username, but I believe it makes it easier to debug issues if they arise.

**Additional context**

Please note that the user can define their own name; this is just to ensure that the defaults never clash, adding "sharp edges" to the experience.

issues.title: Check if Workspace or Docker Container Name exists
issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
If you use the `daytona create` command and use a name that already exists (either as a Daytona Workspace or Docker Container) the TUI will not warn you, but rather will through an error at create. FATA[0011] 

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Type `daytona create`
2. Select any repo and follow to creation
3. Type `daytona create` again, same repo and follow to creation
4. See error
```FATA[0011] failed to create workspace: workspace already exists ```

**Expected behavior**
Expected that on **Workspace name** step, that on `enter` Daytona verifies if the names exists and if so pauses the flow and warns the user that the name is in use and to type a different name .                                                        

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
OS: MacOS 13.5.1 (22G90)
Browser: n/a
Daytona Version: v0.13.0-alpha.7

issues.title: Daytona code command missing info about workspaces

Please describe.** When creating a workspace, the following information is displayed: | Workspace | `WORKSPACENAME` | | Editor | `CURRENTIDESET` | | State | `STATEOFWORKSPACE` | | Repository | `REPOSITORYURL` | However, when selecting a Workspace to `code`, the displayed information is different: - `WORKSPACENAME` - `ID` - `REPOSITORYNAME` (to be clear, this is different from `REPOSITORYURL`) **Describe the solution you'd like** My suggestion would be to make the information consistent. issues.title: Improve help command
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

The `daytona --help` command should "recursively" display all subcommands for each main command so that users can view all functionalities more easily


For example:
This is the default help view for the root command:

![image](https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona/assets/25279767/628c891d-2bbe-4b50-88b1-c88dc5317a71)

issues.title: Suggest to Migrate Target command to top level
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I have found a few issues with `target` being a subcommand of `server`:

- Lack of visibility: as a new user, I didn't know that `target` exists.
- It's not clear how `server` is connected to `target`.
- It seems that the `target` command and its subcommands: `set`, `list`, `remove`, are used more often than `server` (which is used mainly just once). Because of this, the commands become very long, which is not the best user experience.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
My suggestion would be for `target` to become a top-level command: `daytona target`.

issues.title: Display tailscale connection delays in workspace creation
issues.body:
@Tpuljak i would suggest that if it establishes a connection under 3 seconds, then proceed as it does now. After 3 seconds would show a log to the user something along the lines of "Connection to tailscale is taking longer than usual" With this the user is prepared and informed what the issues is. 5 seconds after that we can display an error along the lines of "Connection to tailscale could not be established and WS creation aborted. Please check your Internet connection or the status of the tailscale"

_Originally posted by @ivan-burazin in https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona/issues/427#issuecomment-2089890536_

I suggest showing something like this after 5 seconds:
```
[SPINNER] Connection to tailscale is taking longer than usual
```

issues.title: Daytona create format
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

As previously discussed, we should consider changing create command's format to allow the following to work:
`daytona create https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona`
instead of the current format:
`daytona create DaytonaWorkspace -r https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona`

The workspace name would need to be generated. Defaulting  to the suggested name currently used in the TUI makes the most sense. What should we do if the name is already taken? Simply append the order number? `daytona-workspace` -> `daytona-workspace2` Also an optional workspaceName flag could be useful to override the default value.

Multi project workspace's repos would be defined as an array or arguments:
`daytona create https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona https://github.com/foo/bar https://github.com/foo/baz`

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Run `daytona server -d && daytona ls`
2. Observe that the api is not accessible.

**Expected behavior**
`daytona server -d` should exit the command only if the server health check passes. This will make sure that the api is accessible to subsequent commands.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: any
 - Daytona Version: v0.12.1

issues.title: daytona server target remove - removing target leaves workspaces in the list

labels.name: never stale
labels.description: An issue that never goes stale

issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
When using the `daytona server target remove` command to remove a target, the command successfully removes the target but leaves the associated workspaces in the list. This prevents users from easily removing those workspaces later.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Use the `daytona server target remove` command to remove a target.
2. Check the list of workspaces.
3. Try to interact with workspace created on the removed target.

**Expected behavior**
After removing a target, the associated workspaces should also be removed from the list, allowing users to easily manage their workspace configurations. Also user should be alerted that removing the target will impact management of the workspaces.

**Additional context**
This issue can lead to clutter in the workspace list and confusion for users trying to clean up their configurations.

The config form should allow user to set the custom container image and the default os user.

issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
Currently, we define the devcontainer image as `ghcr.io/daytonaio/go-devcontainer:main`.

The devcontainer image is repulled on each devcontainer rebuild.

issues.title: Default profile lockout

**To Reproduce**

2. Generate a new api key and chose "yes" to save the auth key to the default profile
3. Revoke the new api key
4. You are locked out of daytona default profile

**Expected behavior**
Local profile should not be affected by the api key. It should not be even possible to set the api key for the local profile.

issues.title: daytona server target set with docker provider needs intervention by the user on the remote machine

`sudo chmod 666 /var/run/docker.sock`

**Expected behavior**
Ideally, docker provider should make sure everything is set and ready for work (install docker and chmod sock). Or we need to document this well, maybe even in TUI.

issues.title: Container registries
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Daytona lacks the ability to add container registries credentials to allow providers configuring the access to private CRs.

Daytona lacks the ability for adding container registry credentials needed for providers to configure access to private container registries (CRs). This functionality is crucial for scenarios where teams or organizations utilize private repositories for their container images due to security or proprietary concerns.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Implement the container registry credentials management and allow setting the registry credentials reference in the Project configuration. 
Implement the api call to allow workspace providers to retrieve the credentials.

issues.title: Custom project image
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
There is no option for using custom container image for project containers.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Add "image" property to the Workspace Create method. The "image" property should be available to the Provider.

issues.title: Agent host mode
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Providers for VM based instances need a service that establishes a reverse proxy connection from the VM instance to the Daytona server (or remote provisioner) to allow Provider to connect to the Docker daemon running on the VM instance.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A "host mode" can be added to the Agent entrypoint that will instruct the Agent to only establish the connection and skipping the repository init.

**Additional context**
https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona/issues/362#issuecomment-2051715043

issues.title: Project uptime
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently, the project info has `started` and `finished` as props. These props were influenced by what the Docker provider offers but is not something that all providers can satisfy. (e.g. the Digital Ocean provider can not provide the start time of a droplet).

**Describe the solution you'd like**
We should implement an `uptime` property in a project. This property should be set via the API. The agent will periodically send its uptime to the server and the server will store that information in the project store.

**Additional context**
Uptime should only be presented to the user in the verbose workspace list.

issues.title: Provide ability to select more workspaces for deletion
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
When creating multiple workspaces, such as for reviewing pull requests, users should be able to select and delete multiple workspaces simultaneously. Now it is only possible to delete one by one.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The interface should also offer the option to select multiple workspaces for removal.

issues.title: Workspace creation with remote target leads to "FATA[0026] failed to create workspace: unexpected EOF"

labels.name: Needs Investigation
labels.description: This issue needs a team member to investigate its status.

labels.name: never stale
labels.description: An issue that never goes stale

issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
I am trying to spin up a development environment on a remote target server using Daytona CLI but when I run `daytona create` and select my target server, the workspace creation script stops at "Workspace creation request submitted" with the following error:
`FATA[0026] failed to create workspace: unexpected EOF`.

Moreover, after this, my daytona installation seems to be compromised as, when I do `daytona server target set`, daytona says it didn't find any provider, not even the docker-provider that I used to create the target just before running `daytona create`. I am forced to restart the daytona server in order for the provider to show again.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. On the local machine, create a new target using docker-provider with `daytona server target set`.
2. Give the target a name, let's say "test".
3. Set up the target using the default container image, the 22 remote port and the default socket path. In my particular setup, I don't need to use a password.
4. Choose the appropriate SSH private key to connect to this server.
5. Create a new dev environment with `daytona create`. Choose a GitHub URL. Give the workspace a name and choose the remote target you just created.
6. See the error. When I first did this I had `FATA[0026]` but the code sometimes changes. Doing these steps again I had `FATA[0085]` but with the same "unexpected EOF" message.

**Expected behavior**
I expected Daytona to correctly spin up my workspace on my remote private server.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: 
     - local: macOS Ventura 13.4
     - server: Ubuntu 20.04.6 LTS
 - Daytona Version: v0.10.0

**Additional context**
The remote server is a personal server hidden behind a VPN. I was connected to the VPN when I tried spinning up the dev environment. I can access it via ssh using a simple ssh command. The server has docker installed. The server does not have access to my private GitHub but I don't think it is the issue here as I tried to set everything up with a public GitHub repository and it still failed.

issues.title: Add support for RustRover

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Add support for RustRover and allow it to be selected thru the Daytona CLI and thru Jetbrains Gateway.

issues.title: Provider configuration UX
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
There are plans to add many more Providers other than the Docker Provider to Daytona. The properties they need for configuration of e.g. VM characteristics such as the OS/arch combination need to be strictly defined in a specific format like image name, build name+version etc.

These values are hard to guess for the user and "recognition over recall" would be necessary to ensure good UX. This is an easier task for web apps than terminals because of the interactivity regarding dynamic substring-based suggestions when typing in the input values and simple and efficient dropdown components.

We need to research a way to implement this kind of UX enhancement that would combine the suggestions from a fixed set of suggestion strings (from a e.g. provider-specific config file) as well as allowing custom input for more specific entries.

This kind of component should be made as a custom Charm piece that is similarly designed to the existing TUI and should work well with any input type combination from a predefined provider config format.

issues.title: Git commit signing
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
An increasing number of projects are requiring verified / signed commits. **https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/managing-commit-signature-verification/signing-commits** 

For GitHub there are two general approaches to commit signing:
* [Sign with SSH key](https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/managing-commit-signature-verification/about-commit-signature-verification#ssh-commit-signature-verification)
* [Sign with GPG key](https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/managing-commit-signature-verification/about-commit-signature-verification#gpg-commit-signature-verification) 

SSH agent forwarding can be part of the solution here (both ssh and gpg can be forwarded over ssh). There is also changes that need to be made with the `.gitconfig` ([gpg](https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/managing-commit-signature-verification/telling-git-about-your-signing-key)/[ssh](https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/managing-commit-signature-verification/telling-git-about-your-signing-key#telling-git-about-your-ssh-key))

This is certainly advanced but its needed for these projects which are becoming more common.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

I think this is part of a larger re-envisioning of git credentials. In the Daytona config (global, profile, etc). I should be able to say, I want to use ssh or oauth. In a commercial setting, ops is likely to want to mandate you have to use ssh or oauth. If I choose ssh, do I also want to setup for signed commits, great plumb that through all the way. SSH agent forward, gitconfig with the right settings, etc. Similarly, do I have gpg and do I want to forward it? Plumb that through.

This is related to #369. 

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

This is also related to Yubikey support. Yubikeys can act as ssh/gpg hardware which could add complexity (or perhaps that is solved by general ssh forwarding). Someone would need to do more research.

issues.title: Prebuilds
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Having to wait for the build process each time the workspace is created can be frustrating.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Prebuilds can speedup workspace creation by executing build ahead of creation, usually triggered by changes in the project repository.
A Prebuild can be configured per project. It should allow user to define a specific branch, frequency and whether the build will be continuous or clean.

issues.title: TUI update
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Current Daytona TUI is done ad-hoc and is not consistent.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The proposed TUI design is attached.
[CLI.pdf](https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona/files/14899169/CLI.pdf)

issues.title: Workspace Plugin
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
-

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Daytona should provide Workspace Plugin interface that would allow writing plugins that would activate on Workspace life-cycle hooks like PreStart, PreStop, PostStart, PostCreate, etc.
Workspace Plugins could allow users to automate the personalization layer of the development environment. The plugins could also allow to automate specific jobs that do not belong to the development environment configuration in general.
 
The goal of this feature request is to discuss the scope of the plugin and define the interface.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Dev container, for example, allows executing commands on the container lifecycle hooks. But this does not overlap with the idea of Daytona Workspace Plugin as the plugin should allow Daytona specific functionalities that should not bloat the dev container configuration. Note that dev container is just a reference, but the same logic applies for any other configuration standard.

issues.title: Project image builder
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Atm. Daytona can only use the default base image for Project containers.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
If a repository contains Devcontainer (or other supported dev env config format), Daytona should (or be able to) build the base image for the Project based on the configuration. The built image should get pushed to the container registry associated with the Provider used to provision the workspace. 

The goal of this Feature request is to define the scope of the Image builder component and the implementation details.

issues.title: Workspace Templates and Project Configuration
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Daytona does not have a mechanism to define reusable Workspace and Project configurations.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Adding Workspace Templates and Project Configurations the user would be able to create complex workspaces quickly from the predefined templates.

Each Project is related to the single git repository. Project Configuration should allow defining the custom base image used for the compute instance provisioned for the project, Project specific environment variables, custom image build instructions (Devcontainer, custom script), image build frequency (prebuilds) etc.

Workspace is comprised of one or more Projects. Workspace Template should allow easy Project composition.

These configurations are not an alternative to Dev container, Nix etc. and are not planned to be included in the project repository. They are Daytona specific and are created and managed by the user in the Daytona application.
However they should be easy to share between users.

The scope if this Feature request is to draft the both the Project Configuration schema and Workspace Template schema.

issues.title: 'daytona remove' interface should ask for confirmation
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
When using the interface to remove workspaces, users can accidentally select the wrong one and delete it without being asked for confirmation. Additionally, when testing and creating multiple workspaces, such as for reviewing pull requests, users should have the ability to select and delete multiple workspaces simultaneously.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The interface for deleting workspaces in Daytona 'daytona remove' should prompt users for confirmation when deleting a workspace. The interface should also offer the option to select multiple workspaces for removal.

Warning: Destination directory /usr/local/bin does not exist.

           mkdir -p /usr/local/bin
```

issues.title: Installer script doesn't check for Docker
issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
The installer script doesn't check to see if the user has Docker installed as a prerequisite to using Daytona. Once Daytona is installed, it *does* spit this error message out when you try to create a workspace, but it could be made friendlier and caught earlier in the onboarding process:

```
FATA[0062] failed to create workspace: Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Run the Daytona install script as described in the README.

**Expected behavior**
The install script should either suggest the user installs Docker and/or bail until it detects the Docker socket is present on the system. 

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: macOS 14.4
 - Daytona Version: 0.9.0

issues.body:

Please stop the Daytona Server before continuing

issues.title: Generic Git Provider
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
#280 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
We can implement a Generic Git Provider that will authenticate with http/ssh.
The provider will skip most (all) of the methods for browsing repositories, branches etc.

issues.title: Server Daemon UX
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Minor changes to the daemon command set. The current way the Daytona Server is being daemonized might be slightly confusing at first glance. This is what the commands do now:

`daytona server` - runs the server in the current terminal session
`daytona server -d `- registers, starts the daemon process
`daytona server stop `- stops, unregisters the daemon process
`daytona server restart` - stops, unregisters, registers, starts daemon process

Daemonized state should be the default way to run the server and starting and stopping the server shouldn't always register/unregister the systemd/launchd service. Also, this makes the service autostart on boot which should be an optional feature.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Use the "serve" verb for a Server running in the current terminal session if someone prefers that approach
Separate the registering/unregistering and starting/stopping commands
Add a enable/disable command - using the same naming as systemd

Proposed format:

`daytona serve` - runs the server in the current terminal session
`daytona server` - registers and starts the daemon process

`daytona server start` - starts the daemon process
`daytona server stop` - stops the daemon process
`daytona server restart` - restarts the daemon process

`daytona server init` - registers the daemon process
    (alias `daytona server register`) 
`daytona server destroy`	- unregisters the daemon process
    (alias `daytona server unregister`) 
`daytona server reload` - stops, unregisters, registers, starts the daemon process

`daytona server enable` - enables the daemon on startup
`daytona server disable` - disables the daemon on startup



**Additional notes**
Also add the line "To view logged information use `daytona server logs -f`" to the command starting the daemon

issues.title: WSL2 VSCode support
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Running Daytona on WSL2 doesn't work for VSCode IDE as VSCode uses the native Windows SSH client and Daytona edits the Linux SSH config file to prepare SSH connection configs for workspaces. This wouldn't pose an issue most of the time, but Daytona uses a ProxyCommand under the hood which calls "daytona ssh-proxy" and is defined in the SSH config that naturally searches for the daytona binary on the Linux part of the filesystem.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
This isn't a Daytona specific issue, rather a missing feature from the remote development plugin. Ideally, we could pass a "remote ssh path" flag when calling the "code" CLI and set it to the ssh of our choice. We can create a ticket to see if this is doable with the official support but until then we should consider another option.

One way to fix this is to show the user the instructions / make script that can be run from WSL to:
1. Make a wsl_ssh.bat script with content: `C:\Windows\system32\wsl.exe ssh %*`
	at `C:\Users\<USERNAME>\AppData\Roaming\bin\wsl_ssh.bat `
2. Edit the VSCode user settings.json with: `"remote.SSH.path": "C:\\Users\\<USERNAME>\\AppData\\Roaming\\bin\\wsl_ssh.bat"`,
	at `C:\Users\<USERNAME>\AppData\Roaming\Code\User\settings.json`
3. Create a symlink to continuously sync native SSH config with WSL2 config
	`ln -s /mnt/c/Users/<USERNAME>/.ssh/config config`

This would be a `hack/windows/vscode_wsl_ssh.sh` script with a couple of lines of bash code.

*To check if the current installation is in WSL we can do `uname -a` and see if it contains "microsoft"/"WSL". 
Based on that we can then print out instructions or a docs URL to the user. User would be able to do the steps manually if they prefer it instead of running the script.

**Additional context**

A problem with this option is that the user might not want the default SSH client to be the WSL client as this would affect all VSCode operations that use SSH, even outside of Daytona. 
It can be investigated further if creating a VSCode "profile" for Daytona would be feasible as it would have its own set of config settings. The "--profile" flag is available for use in the "code" CLI and this profile would be only used by Daytona, allowing the user to continue using their default profile for other work.

Another approach is to see if a Daytona VSCode extension could resolve this by handling the SSH client switching part.

There is no strict way to implementing this. We are open to suggestions.

issues.title: Project environment variables
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Currently, the docker provider has a list of environment variables hardcoded when creating a project.
E.g.
```go
		"DAYTONA_WS_ID=" + project.WorkspaceId,
		"DAYTONA_WS_DIR=" + path.Join("/workspaces", project.Name),
		"DAYTONA_WS_PROJECT_NAME=" + project.Name,
		"DAYTONA_WS_PROJECT_REPOSITORY_URL=" + project.Repository.Url,
		"DAYTONA_SERVER_API_KEY=" + project.ApiKey,
		"DAYTONA_SERVER_VERSION=" + serverVersion,
		"DAYTONA_SERVER_URL=" + serverUrl,
		"DAYTONA_SERVER_API_URL=" + serverApiUrl,
```

This is not ideal as all providers would have to hardcode this information when creating a project.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Environment variables should be passed with the project to the provider and the provider should add all of them when creating a project.

issues.title: Provide a project startup script utility
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

All projects must start by downloading the Daytona binary and executing `daytona agent`. This is done in the docker provider by hardcoding `fmt.Sprintf("curl -sf -L %s | sudo -E bash && daytona agent", serverDownloadUrl)`. This is a bit hard to maintain as it requires all providers to know this piece of code.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Daytona should provide a utility for getting the startup script with the provided `serverDownloadUrl` that all providers can reuse.

issues.title: Anonymized Telemetry
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Without the telemetry feature, we lack information to improve the product beyond user feedback. We have no insight into the performance problems or application errors users encounter.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Daytona should collect anonymized telemetry data to help us understand how the tool is being used, identify areas for improvement, and prioritize new features and enhancements.

**Additional context**
This data collected must be in compliance with GDPR and other applicable privacy regulations.

issues.title: Implement a logging utility for providers
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

The biggest "issue" is related to the workspace creation logs. They are simple "static" logs generated by the server. Providers do not have a way to influence this log (other than knowing the hardcoded path of the log file).

**Describe the solution you'd like**

A utility should be implemented that providers can use to log events related to workspaces and projects.

issues.title: Implement a server healtcheck
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Currently, we have a [5 second timeout hardcoded](https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona/blob/main/pkg/cmd/server/server.go#L57) when detecting if the server has started. If the server exits within the 5 seconds, it means it failed to start. This is not ideal as it isn't a strong guarantee that the server actually started.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

We need to implement a healtcheck method that will return if the server is started or not.

issues.title: Allow user to set no default IDE

I tend to use neovim via ssh. So I don't want to have VS Code or Jetbrains open after every create. Allow me to set a no-op default IDE. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
As it is now, I either pick an IDE I don't use or get an error on every create about no IDE set. Let me set a no-op IDE that does nothing on create.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Alternatively, let me configure / add a setting to make `--skip-ide` as the default behavior.

issues.title: Basic question about the point of the software
issues.body:
Similar to issue #100, I have basic questions. I retired as a software engineer in 2000, so I never learned about containers and other modern development tools. I program locally in Windows only (my remote server runs Linux), I use something similar to notepad for editing, and currently do most of my programming in the primitive language PHP, which has the advantage of being accessible securely by anyone in the world using a browser.

I see that Daytona requires Visual Code or Visual Studio Code, containers, and other tools created by Microsoft (in addition to basic web stuff like SSH).

So my question is: is all open software development now done using Microsoft tools? Is this now standard everywhere, even at Google, where they presumably use the go language? No one uses customizable editors like Emacs anymore? Most programmers use purchased tools, like IDEs? Or is Daytona aimed at just those developers who use a specific type of Linux/Windows/Microsoft technology?

issues.title: Serve binaries from the Daytona Server
issues.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Currently, projects use the [get-server](https://github.com/daytonaio/daytona/blob/main/hack/get-server.sh) script that's hosted by Daytona to download the binary and initialize the Agent.

This is a bit problematic because it places a hard requirement on all projects to have access to that URL when the only requirement for projects should be access to the Server.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

The Server should serve binaries for all OSs from its own endpoint. If the requested binary is not present on the Server fs, it should automatically download it for future requests.

❯ daytona create test -r https://github.com/metcalfc/simple-astro

issues.title: Add a doctor command
